Award.AwardTitle: II-NEW: An Experimental Infrastructure for Cross-Domain Research in Wireless Computing, Cybersecurity and Data Mining

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Among the developments that are pushing the boundary of computer science and engineering research, these stand out: the emergence of Big Data as a reality, pushing the need for scalable data analytics (e.g., data mining), the proliferation of wireless and cellular networks, and the deployment of large scale cyber-physical systems. Every year, petabytes of new data are collected and stored by companies and organizations, prompting the need for scalable data mining to make sense of the data that has been collected. Further, the proliferation of wireless and cellular networks has enabled the advent of mobile and nomadic computing. This proliferation has also given rise to many new challenges.

This new computing research infrastructure enables research into cross-layer protocols for cognitive radio networks, wireless security energy management techniques for mobile devices, designing security for cyber-physical systems, malware detection and prevention for mobile devices, design of deeply embedded systems for monitoring water distribution infrastructure, new tools to perform scalable Time Series analysis, tools to perform Bayesian inference in critical data mining problems, and to perform Metagenome annotation and comparison. It supports undergraduate and graduate courses on these topics. Software developed under this program and supporting data will be made available to the research community, strengthening efforts for technology transfer.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project at the Volgenau School of Engineering at George Mason University aimed to create a new experimental infrastructure for supporting cross-cutting research and teaching in three areas: data mining, mobile and wireless systems, and cyber-security. Faculty members from Computer Science and Electrical and Computer Engineering collaborated on the selection, purchase and installation of state-of-the-art hardware that enabled us to explore new research idea, begin new collaborations and train the next generation of engineers and scientists.

 As a result of funds from this project Mason was able to purchase a large compute cluster that is now being used for bioinformatics, networking and cyber-security research. This cluster became part of the overall Mason research computing infrastructure and is available to faculty members across campus.  Details are available at http://orc.gmu.edu. 

 We obtained a large number of mobile devices for anti-malware research, an area critical for the protection of smart phones. Project funds also supported purchase of hardware for research into the security of Cyber-Physical Systems.  For instance, we obtained several of the latest generation of smart and connected automotive components.

 We purchased a variety of software-definable radios and testing and measurement equipment to study issues related to Spectrum Sensing and Cognitive Radio (CR). Understanding and improving these technologies is essential to effective management of the crowded wireless spectrum. This equipment is also used for graduate and undergraduate projects.

We also purchased a number of embedded wireless sensor nodes. Developing new protocols for wireless sensing nodes (WSN) is a key element enabling the growth of the Internet-of-Things.  Both the CR and WSN testbeds are actively used by a number of researchers and their students.  

The infrastructure supports more than 15 faculty members at Mason, along with their graduate students.  Using equipment purchased since project inception enabled us to collectively publish approximately 70 peer reviewed journal and conference papers.   All of these papers include graduate students as co-authors.  The infrastructure provides essential support for a number of our Ph.D. students.  Further, this level of infrastructural support was one of the factors that enabled the CS department to successfully recruit new tenure track faculty members in Cyber Physical Systems.

Some specific technical outcomes include

--Showing that collaboratively sensing the wireless spectrum over time yields significant gains in detection performance, particularly under low Signal-to-Noise conditions.

--Starting new research in Software Definable Networking (SDN). We implemented a fine-grained traffic monitoring using the Open vSwitch (OVS) software running on SDN nodes. We purchased two Pica 8 switches and built an SDN testbed.

 --Using our compute cluster to perform Moving Target defense experiments and simulation for large-scale Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks.

-- Using our mobile devices to develop techniques for malware evasion detection, resource exhaustion attack detection. For instance, we were able to enhance our abilities to detect PDF malware and expose resource exhaustion attacks against mobile devices and programs.  We also developed a new class of Android-based attacks.

--The design, implementation and public release of open-source code to support broadcasting in massively scaled embedded wireless systems.  The code is available at https://osf.io/nr7fm/ 

Taken as a whole, this infrastructure supports research that benefits current and future efforts in healthcare and medicine, enhances the security of our handheld devices and networked systems, and supports economic growth and public safety by improving wireless networks and Internet-of-things applications.
